information:
The Democratic primary for Attorney General of Virginia on June 17, 2025, features two candidates: Jay Jones and Shannon Taylor. Jones is a former Norfolk state delegate and assistant attorney general with previous statewide campaign experience from a 2021 run for the same office. His platform includes a focus on consumer protection, civil rights, and labor justice. Taylor has served as the Henrico County Commonwealth's Attorney for over 11 years, emphasizing her background in law enforcement and prosecution. Both candidates have publicly stated their opposition to policies of the Trump administration.

As of early May 2025, campaign finance reports indicated that Jay Jones held a significant fundraising advantage. He had raised approximately $1.8 million, with $1.4 million in cash on hand. In contrast, reports for Shannon Taylor showed she had raised over $1 million. Earlier reports from the first quarter of the year indicated Jones had a roughly 2-to-1 fundraising lead over Taylor, having raised approximately $900,000 to her $525,000.

Jay Jones has secured endorsements from several high-profile Virginia Democrats, including former Governors Terry McAuliffe and Ralph Northam, as well as U.S. Representative Bobby Scott. Shannon Taylor's endorsements include support from the Fairfax County Commonwealth's Attorney and some former attorneys general. The winner of the primary will face the incumbent Republican, Jason Miyares, in the general election.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 2 weeks (primary is June 17, 2025; results likely known June 17–18)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — Jones narrowly wins the Democratic primary
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Taylor consolidates Northern Virginia with a late-breaking edge (e.g., a Washington Post endorsement, visible NoVA institutional support, and/or a late cash surge), outperforms in higher-turnout suburbs, and overcomes Jones’s Hampton Roads strength; or a negative story blunts Jones’s momentum. Extremely unlikely but possible annulment if the primary were not held by June 30.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Jones leverages his fundraising lead and high-profile endorsements to dominate paid media and field, turns out Hampton Roads and Black voters, competes adequately in NoVA and Richmond exurbs, and benefits from early voting already underway, yielding a modest statewide margin.
forecast.rationale:
- Priors and current signals: Two-candidate statewide primary with no credible public polling cited. In such races, fundraising and endorsement edges typically translate into a small but real advantage. Per the assistant’s report, Jones has raised about $1.8M (roughly a 2:1 edge earlier in the year) and holds marquee endorsements (former Governors McAuliffe and Northam; Rep. Bobby Scott). Taylor, the long-time Henrico Commonwealth’s Attorney, has raised just over $1M and has notable law-enforcement–aligned backing including the Fairfax County Commonwealth’s Attorney and some former AGs.
- Turnout/coalitions: No governor mega-primary appears to be driving turnout this cycle, so mobilization capacity and name ID matter more. Jones’s prior 2021 statewide run likely gives him broader residual name recognition and a built network, especially in Hampton Roads and among Black Democrats. Taylor’s profile may resonate in NoVA suburban law-and-order–focused pockets, and the Fairfax CA endorsement is meaningful in a region that often dominates Democratic primary turnout.
- Early voting: Virginia’s early voting has been underway since early May, slightly lowering the impact of very late developments and favoring the better-funded ground and mail operations—likely an edge for Jones.
- Status quo weighting: With about two weeks left and no hard evidence of a Taylor surge, the world likely changes slowly; the status quo favors the candidate with more money, institutional backing, and prior statewide exposure—i.e., Jones by a modest margin.
- Why not higher than my forecast: Lack of public polling makes the race uncertain; NoVA turnout frequently decides Democratic primaries, and Taylor has a plausible path there (including potential influence of a Washington Post endorsement if it goes her way). Jones lost statewide in 2021 (to an incumbent), reminding us he is not invulnerable. The fundraising gap, while real, is not overwhelming enough to foreclose an upset.
- Why not lower: Jones’s combined advantages—money, endorsements, prior statewide campaign infrastructure, and likely strength with Black voters—are all consistent with a small favorite in a two-way contest.
- What would move me up: Credible polling showing a Jones lead; confirmation of a Washington Post endorsement for Jones; visible ad-spend superiority in the DC and Hampton Roads markets; union endorsements breaking decisively for Jones; signs of elevated Hampton Roads/Black early vote.
- What would move me down: Reputable polling with Taylor ahead; a Washington Post endorsement for Taylor; a major late infusion of cash or independent expenditure for Taylor dominating DC media; negative news for Jones; signs of unusually strong NoVA turnout relative to Hampton Roads.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Jerrauld "Jay" Jones win the Democratic primary for attorney general of Virginia in the 2025 election?

Question background:
Washington Post: [Former Del. Jay Jones (D) of Norfolk ramps up bid for Virginia AG](https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2024/11/12/virginia-jones-miyares-ag-election/)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if [Jerrauld "Jay" Jones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jay_Jones_(politician)) wins the 2025 Democratic primary for Attorney General of Virginia, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).

The Democratic primary election is currently scheduled for June 17, 2025. If there is no Democratic primary held before June 30, 2025, the question will be **annulled**.


Your research assistant's report says:
The Democratic primary for Attorney General of Virginia on June 17, 2025, features two candidates: Jay Jones and Shannon Taylor. Jones is a former Norfolk state delegate and assistant attorney general with previous statewide campaign experience from a 2021 run for the same office. His platform includes a focus on consumer protection, civil rights, and labor justice. Taylor has served as the Henrico County Commonwealth's Attorney for over 11 years, emphasizing her background in law enforcement and prosecution. Both candidates have publicly stated their opposition to policies of the Trump administration.

As of early May 2025, campaign finance reports indicated that Jay Jones held a significant fundraising advantage. He had raised approximately $1.8 million, with $1.4 million in cash on hand. In contrast, reports for Shannon Taylor showed she had raised over $1 million. Earlier reports from the first quarter of the year indicated Jones had a roughly 2-to-1 fundraising lead over Taylor, having raised approximately $900,000 to her $525,000.

Jay Jones has secured endorsements from several high-profile Virginia Democrats, including former Governors Terry McAuliffe and Ralph Northam, as well as U.S. Representative Bobby Scott. Shannon Taylor's endorsements include support from the Fairfax County Commonwealth's Attorney and some former attorneys general. The winner of the primary will face the incumbent Republican, Jason Miyares, in the general election.

Today is 2025-06-03.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
